bestBHT.bht: The occurrence of the servant of God, not elsewhere found in the superscriptions of St. Paul’s Epistles, is a mark of genuineness. The best sense seems to be that of reference, to bring about, cherish, and perfect their faith as the only true faith which the apostolic office would subserve. This election has its ground in the purpose and will of God from everlasting. The writer is an apostle according to the faith of God's elect, and according to the truth which is contained in the faith, as that truth is intelligently apprehended and held.

Henry Alford: The occurrence of the servant of God, not elsewhere found in the superscriptions of St. Paul’s Epistles, is a mark of genuineness."
The best sense seems to be that which Huther gives,—that of reference, ‘with regard to,’ i.e. to bring about, cherish, and perfect."
Their faith is the only true faith—the only faith which the apostolic office would subserve.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The full expression of his apostolic office answers, in both Epistles, to the design, and is a comprehensive index to the contents.
This election has its ground, not in anything belonging to those thus distinguished, but in the purpose and will of God from everlasting.
Godliness," or "piety," is a term peculiar to the Pastoral Epistles: a fact explained by the apostle having in them to combat doctrine tending to 'ungodliness'.
Albert Barnes: The meaning of the word rendered here, 'according to' - κατὰ kata - is, probably, with reference to; that is, he was appointed to be an apostle with respect to the faith of those whom God had chosen.

God had chosen them to salvation, but he intended that it should be in connection with their believing, and, in order to that, he had appointed Paul to be an apostle that he might go and make known to them the gospel.
The object of the apostleship, as it is of the ministry in general, is to secure the proper acknowledgment of the truth among men.
Marvin Vincent: The norm of the apostolate in each of the three Epistles is unique, and not Pauline.
The writer is an apostle according to the faith of God's elect, and according to the truth which is contained in the faith, as that truth is intelligently apprehended and held.

This addition describes the peculiar and essential character of the truth which is held and known by God's elect, namely, that it is concerned with the fear and obedience of God - all that constitutes true piety.
John Calvin: There is a mutual agreement between my apostleship and the faith of the elect of God; and, therefore, it will not be rejected by any man who is not a reprobate and opposed to the true faith.
But when Paul describes it to be a quality which essentially belongs to faith — to know the truth, he plainly shews that there is no faith without knowledge.

And hence we are also informed, that the greater progress any one has made in godliness, he is so much the better disciple of Christ; and that he ought to be reckoned a true theologian who edifies consciences in the fear of God.
Philip Schaff: The title servant of God, occurring in James 1:1, but nowhere else in Paul’s inscriptions, is a peculiarity which tells against suspicion of forgery.

According to (better, ‘with a view to’), introduces the double design of his apostle-ship, viz: (1) the production of faith in God’s chosen ones (or of that genuine faith which only the chosen have) (cf. Romans 1:5); and (2) the production in believers of a full knowledge ( not ‘acknowledging’ ) of the truth, or entire Gospel revelation.

A dual design: faith and knowledge. Against certain errorists, this truth tends to godliness, a Pauline word frequent in Pastoral Epistles, denoting that religious fear of God in the heart which penetrates and rules the whole conduct.
Archibald T. Robertson: According to the faith of God's elect... κατα πιστιν εκλεκτων θεου."
The knowledge (επιγνωσιν)... 'Full knowledge,' one of Paul's favourite words."
Which is according to godliness (της κατ' ευσεβειαν)...
John Gill: Paul, before his conversion, was a servant of sin, of divers lusts and pleasures, and which he owns in this epistle, Titus 3:3 but being called by grace, he became free from the vassalage of sin, and became a servant of God, and of righteousness.

There are some persons who are styled the elect of God; these are not all men, some are vessels of wrath fitted to destruction, ungodly men, foreordained to condemnation and given up to believe a lie, that they might be damned; nor the Jews only, nor all of them, for though, as a nation, they were chosen, above all others, to many outward privileges, yet they were not chosen to special grace, and eternal glory; only a remnant, according to the election of grace.

The Gospel is a doctrine according to godliness; the truths of it have an influence, both on internal and external godliness; they direct to, and promote the worship and fear of God, and a religious, righteous, sober, and godly life and conversation.
John Wesley: We serve God according to the measure of our faith: we fulfil our public office according to the measure of our knowledge.
The truth that is after godliness - Which in every point runs parallel with and supports the vital, spiritual worship of God; and, indeed, has no other end or scope.
These two verses contain the sum of Christianity, which Titus was always to have in his eye.

bhtAttempts.bht: The occurrence of the servant of God, not elsewhere found in the superscriptions of St. Paul’s Epistles, is a mark of genuineness. The best sense seems to be that of reference, to bring about, cherish, and perfect their faith as the only true faith which the apostolic office would subserve. This election has its ground, not in anything belonging to those thus distinguished, but in the purpose and will of God from everlasting. The writer is an apostle according to the faith of God's elect, and according to the truth which is contained in the faith, as that truth is intelligently apprehended and held. This addition describes the peculiar and essential character of the truth which is held and known by God's elect, namely, that it is concerned with the fear and obedience of God - all that constitutes true piety. The object of the apostleship, as it is of the ministry in general, is to secure the proper acknowledgment of the truth among men.

The occurrence of the servant of God, not elsewhere found in the superscriptions of St. Paul’s Epistles, is a mark of genuineness. The best sense seems to be that of reference, to bring about, cherish, and perfect their faith as the only true faith which the apostolic office would subserve. This election has its ground in the purpose and will of God from everlasting. The writer is an apostle according to the faith of God's elect, and according to the truth which is contained in the faith, as that truth is intelligently apprehended and held.

The occurrence of the servant of God, not elsewhere found in the superscriptions of St. Paul’s Epistles, is a mark of genuineness. The best sense seems to be that which Huther gives—to bring about, cherish, and perfect their faith as the only true faith which the apostolic office would subserve. This election has its ground in the purpose and will of God from everlasting. The writer is an apostle according to the faith of God's elect, and according to the truth which is contained in the faith.

The occurrence of the servant of God, a mark of genuineness, signifies the writer's purpose to bring about, cherish, and perfect the faith of God's elect. This election, rooted in the purpose and will of God, highlights the essential character of the truth held by the chosen ones—it is concerned with true piety, fear, and obedience of God. The object of the apostleship, and ministry in general, is to secure the proper acknowledgment of this truth, promoting a deep knowledge of it among believers.

The occurrence of the servant of God, a mark of genuineness, points to the writer's purpose: to bring about, cherish, and perfect the faith of God's elect. This election is rooted in God's purpose and will, and the writer is an apostle according to the faith of God's elect. They hold the truth which is concerned with true piety, fear, and obedience of God. The object of the apostleship is to secure the proper acknowledgment of this truth, promoting a deep knowledge of it among believers.
